title-group.article-title: Assessment of multicomponent hydrogel scaffolds of poly(acrylic acid-2-hydroxy ethyl methacrylate)/gelatin for tissue engineering applications

article-meta.aff: Centre for Biomedical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, India, 110016

author-notes.corresp: Veena Koul, Centre for Biomedical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India. Email: veenak_iitd@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The article describes the design of the multicomponent hydrogel system of poly(acrylic acid-HEMA)/gelatin for tissue engineering application. Derivative of polycaprolactone-diol (polycaprolactone diacrylate (PCL-DAr)) was used to cross-link acrylate monomers whereas gelatin was kept free for cell proliferation. Epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG), an anti-oxidant phytochemical, was loaded by diffusion method. Its in vitro release study in PBS (pH 6.5) at 37 ± 0.2°C (75 rpm) revealed a sustained release profile upto 20 days. Fitting of drug release data in Korsmeyer-Peppas model equation revealed probable release mechanism through the value of release coefficient (n), which was found to depend on formulations composition. Drug-polymer interaction, thermal behavior, and surface morphology were investigated by attenuated total reflectance–Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and scanning electron microscopic (SEM). Swelling behavior of hydrogel in PBS (pH 6.5 and 7.4, 0.2 M) and in distilled water was found to increase with increasing AAc/HEMA ratio. Compression modulus decreased from 203 ± 3.7 KPa to 11.6 ± 1.1KPa, at 30% strain, whereas displacement values significantly increased from 3.2 ± 0.2 to 4.7 ± 0.6 mm at 20 N force (p < 0.05), with increasing AAc/HEMA ratio. Percentage cell viability was analyzed using indirect 3-[4, 5-dimethylthiazolyl-2]-2,5-diphenyltetrazo-liumbromide (MTT) assay with fibroblast L929 cells; showed ≥92.3% cell viability after 24 h incubation. Cell proliferation on the scaffold surface was found to increase with incorporation of HEMA in P(AAc)/G cross-linked hydrogel matrix upto a certain extent. These biocompatible, elastic, and swellable hydrogels can serve as a matrix for drug delivery and tissue engineering applications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hydrogels are three-dimensional (3D) cross-linked polymeric structures, possess water retention capacity, and have soft tissue-like consistency. Their inherent water-absorbing property makes them a suitable architecture for controlled drug delivery applications for dermatological patches or films, soft tissue regeneration (bone, cartilage, skin, blood vessel, etc), and for various other biomedical and pharmaceutical applications.1–6 Controlled release of potent drugs at the desired site of application is a crucial and desirable property of drug carrier which offers many advantages (i.e. higher therapeutic efficacy with minimum drug induced side effects, patient compliance as well as cost effectiveness of the drug regime) over conventional drug delivery systems.7–10 The drug release profile from the hydrogel is influence by many biological (pH, temperature, and biochemical microenvironment at the site of application) and physicochemical (functionality of polymer network) factors. These factors ultimately affect swelling, degradation, compression, and other important properties of the matrices.7,11–13 In spite of many favorable properties, hydrogels are devoid of mechanical strength, which limits their biomedical and pharmaceutical applications. Various research schools improved the mechanical strength and elasticity by formulating interpenetrating polymeric network (IPNs) matrices and by incorporating nanocomposite materials.14–18

For adhesion and proliferation of cells, we need platforms that possess biological activity as well as strength and elasticity. Various natural and synthetic biomaterials have been explored by the researchers for the hydrogel synthesis for numerous biomedical and pharmaceutical applications.6,7,19,20 We authors designed a multicomponent hydrogel scaffold based on poly (acrylic acid-2-hydroxy ethyl methacrylate)/gelatin. They integrated chemically, morphologically, and functionally, resulting into novel hydrogel system with defined functionality.

Polyacrylic acid (PAAc) is an FDA-approved anionic polymer, which have excellent swelling properties in alkaline media. On the other hand, a non-ionic monomer, hydroxyethyl-methacrylate (HEMA), possessing limited water absorption capacity, was added in varying ratio with AAc to regulate swelling and other physicochemical properties. Elasticity and extracellular matrix (ECM) mimetic properties were introduced by incorporating gelatin into this system. Gelatin is a natural polypeptide comprised of three polypeptide chains arranged in α-helical structure.17 Authors choose it as their first choice owing to its versatile properties viz. non-immunogenicity, biocompatibility, cell responsiveness and cost-effectiveness.2,7,21

Epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG) is a major poly-phenolic compound from green tea possessing excellent antitumor and wound healing potential due to its anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and free radical scavenging properties. Moreover, at low concentration, EGCG promotes the angiogenesis and re-epithelization by triggering myofibroblasts and keratinocytes. In case of wound healing application, an optimum concentration of EGCG is required for achieving maximum healing rate.22–24

With consideration of above facts and desirability, multicomponent hydrogel scaffold of PAAc, HEMA, and gelatin have been constructed using polycaprolactone diacrylate (PCL-DAr) as a cross-linking agent. The suitable polymers were selected to meet the desired properties such as swelling, elasticity, biocompatibility, and controlled drug release profile. Gelatin was intercalated into the acrylate network without cross-linking. The effect of feed composition on EGCG release profile and kinetics were investigated using fickian diffusion model and Korsmeyer-Peppas model. Physicochemical characterizations of matrices were carried out by attenuated total reflectance-Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectra, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and scanning electron microscopic (SEM) examination. The compression properties, weight loss profile, and equilibrium swelling ratio was also investigated as a prerequisite characterization of hydrogel formulations. The biocompatibility studies were performed by 3-[4, 5-dimethylthiazolyl-2]-2,5-diphenyltetrazo-liumbromide (MTT) assay and the effect of PAc/P (HEMA) ratio on cell proliferation were established using fibroblast L929 cells. The aim of the present study was to formulate a biocompatible hydrogel scaffold for soft tissue engineering particularly for wound healing.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Gelatin type A (From bovine skin, bloom strength ≈300, IEP ∼8.7) and polycaprolactone diol (Mw ∼7 530) purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, USA, acryloyl chloride and hydroxyl ethyl-methacrylate (HEMA) from Merck India Pvt Ltd., Goa, India. Acrylic acid, ammonium per sulphate (APS), tetramethylethylene diamine (TEMED), and triethylamine (TEA) purchased from Qualizens India Pvt Ltd, Mumbai, India. Cell culture plates (24 wells) and cell culture flask (25 mL) from Tarsons India Pvt Ltd., Mumbai. Mouse dermal fibroblast L929 secondary culture cells procured from National Centre for Cell Science, Pune, India. Dulbecco modified eagle media (DMEM), fetal bovine serum (FBS) purchased from Sera international Lbs, New Delhi, India. All organic solvents (Qualizens India Pvt Ltd, Mumbai, India), acrylic acid, and TEA were distilled before use.

sec.title: Synthesis of polycaprolactone diacrylate
sec.p: Diacrylate derivative of polycaprolactone diol (PCL-DAr) was synthesized as per the method described in the previous study7 using polycaprolactone diol (PCL-diol, mol. wt ∼530) and acryloyl chloride. The product was purified by column chromatography (silica gel) using methanol as mobile phase and characterized by FT-IR and 1H-NMR spectroscopy.

sec.title: Preparation of hydrogel composite
sec.p: Interpenetrated hydrogel composites were prepared using thermal initiated redox polymerization method using APS and TEMED as reaction catalysts.7,11 A 20% aqueous solution of gelatin was prepared in oxygen-free distilled water by stirring at 40°C. The required quantity of PCL-DAr (0.5 mol% of vinylic monomers) was dissolved separately in given quantity of acrylic acid and HEMA followed by mixing with gelatin solution by slow stirring in magnetic stirrer. It was set aside for 2 h for removal of air bubbles. Free radical polymerization was initiated by addition of 0.2 mol% APS and TEMED. This polymeric mixture was poured in a suitable petri plate and kept in vacuum oven under N2 atmosphere at 45°C for 6 h, the gel thus formed was carefully dislodged from the petri plate and washed three times with ethanol: water (1:1) at 35°C to remove unreacted monomers (water soluble) and cross-linker (ethanol soluble). Finally, hydrogel samples were dried in vacuum oven at 45°C for 24 h and kept in fused calcium chloride desiccator for further studies.

sec.title: Spectral analysis of hydrogels
sec.p: ATR-FTIR analysis of hydrogels was recorded at a resolution of 4.0 cm−1 using Perkin-Elmer (Spectrum One, USA). All the spectrums were collected for at least three randomly selected discs. The thermal decomposition of hydrogels and individual component were carried out using TGA -Pyres- 6TGA (Perkin Elmer, UK), by heating from 50°C to 750°C at a heating rate of 20°C/min under nitrogen flow.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p: The internal morphology of hydrogel matrices were observed by SEM (EVO 50, Zeiss, USA). Fully swollen hydrogel semi-interpenetrating polymeric network (Semi-IPN) were cut into small disc of 8 mm diameter and lyophilized at −196°C for 36 h after snap freezing in liquid nitrogen. Horizontally sectioned lyophilized discs were mounted on to the base platform for gold coating by vapor deposition technique using vacuum sputter coater (EMI TECK, K550X; Carl Zeiss, Thornwood, NY); at 0.09 mbar vacuum pressure.

sec.title: Equilibrium swelling ratio
sec.p: The gravimetric method was used for equilibrium swelling ratio (ESR) determination of hydrogel samples.7 Briefly, immersion of a dried hydrogel disc of ‘10 × 2’ mm dimensions (Approx. 10 mg) in distilled water, PBS (pH 6.5 and 7.4, at 37 ± 0.2°C in an incubator. Swollen discs were lifted at preset time interval of 1, 3, 6, 12 and 24 h, till equilibrium was achieved, blotted on wet filter paper for removal of excess of water from the surface, and weighed on analytical digital balance (n = 3). The ESR was calculated using following formula (1)ESR=Wt-WiWi×100 where Wi is the initial weight of the dry hydrogel disc and Wt is the weight of the swollen polymer at time t.

sec.title: In-vitro weight loss profile
sec.p: In-vitro weight loss profile of the hydrogels was studied by measuring the change in weight as a function of time.7,13 Dry hydrogel discs (approximately 10 mg) were dipped into 5 mL of PBS (pH 6.5, 0.2 M, sodium azide 0.04% w/v) at 37°C. The media was changed every day. At predetermined time interval, sample discs (n = 3) were withdrawn from PBS, washed with distilled water, and dried in vacuum oven at 45°C till constant weight obtained. The percentage (%) weight loss was calculated using the following formula:- (2)% Weight loss=Wt(i)-Wt(t)Wt(i)×100 where Wt(i) is the initial weight of the disc at time zero and Wt(t) is the weight of the disc at time t.

sec.title: Compression properties
sec.p: Compressive mechanical strength of hydrogels and single component hydrogels was measured using uniaxial compression machine (Tinius Olsen, Q4368, H5KS, QMat 5.37 software, PA, USA).7 Cylindrical shaped (diameter 18 mm, thickness 8 mm) fully swollen hydrogel sample were placed between two platforms; compressed at a crosshead speed of 2 mm/min at room temperature and 65 ± 3% relative humidity. Displacement versus force curve was plotted to obtain stress value (MPa) at various % strain (i.e. 10%, 20%, 30%, 40%, and 50%) whereas compressive modulus was calculated from the slope of stress versus strain curve in the range of 0–30% strain.

sec.title: Cell culture
sec.p: Mouse fibroblast L929 cells were procured from National Centre for Cell Science, Pune, India, and were grown in culture flask in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS and 1% Penicillin-Streptomycin-Neomycin solution in a humidified incubator. Upon 70% confluency, cells were detached from the culture flask by addition of 1 mL of 0.25% Trypsin/EDTA solution. The number of cells present in 1 mL of media was counted using heamocytometer and viewed by phase contrast inverted light microscope. After three successful passages, cells were used for viability studies.

sec.title: Cytocompatibility by MTT assay
sec.p: Percentage cell viability of hydrogels extract was evaluated using fibroblast L929 cells by MTT assay25; 5 × 104 cells/well was seeded in 96-well plate with 5% CO2 at 37 ± 0.2°C in an incubator. Semi-IPN discs were dipped into PBS in an incubator shaker at 37 ± 0.2°C for 24 h. A total of 100 µL of that eluent, after filtering through 0.22 µm membrane filter (Millipore™, Billerica, MA), was added to each cell seeded well. At the end of incubation time (24 h time points), 50 µL MTT solution (5 mg/mL) was added to each well and placed at 37 ± 0.2°C, 5% CO2 in a humidified incubator for next 4 h. The formazan crystals were dissolved in 100 µL of dimethyl sulfoxide and optical density (OD) was measured using ELISA plate reader (Microplate reader, Bio-Rad, 680, USA; At 490 nm as measurement filter and 655 nm as reference filter). The violet color developed by a tetrazolium salt, 3-(4, 5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-dyphenyltetra-zoliumbromide (MTT, Sigma-Aldrich, USA). Triton × 100 and PBS were used as negative and positive control, respectively. The % viability of all formulations plotted as a mean ± SD (n = 6) was estimated as per the following formula:- (3)%Cell viability=OD(Test sample)-OD(Negative control)OD(Negative control)×100

sec.title: Fluorescent microscopic observation of cell proliferation
sec.p: The effect of PAAc/HEMA ratio on cell proliferation was observed by capturing fluorescent images of proliferative cells on days 1, 3, and 5. The effect of biochemical functionality (PAA/HEMA/G) of scaffold surface on cell morphology and viability was analyzed. Fibroblasts-laden scaffold circular discs of 1.0 cm diameter were stained with Calcein AM (4 µmoL; as per manufacturer’s instructions). Digital planar images (along the X–Y plane) were captured from the sample surfaces.

sec.title: Drug loading and in vitro release profile
sec.p: Diffusion method was used for loading of EGCG into the hydrogels discs.6 Dry Semi-IPN discs of approx. 10 mg (10 × 2 mm) were dipped into 1%w/v aqueous solution of EGCG at room temperature for 24 h for complete absorption of drug. The exact quantity of required drug solution into hydrogels was calculated from their swelling profiles [Figure 5(A)]. This strategy makes sure that the entire drug absorbed with minimum loss as well as it simplified the drug loading and release calculations. After complete diffusion of EGCG solution, sample discs were dried at room temperature under dark conditions and thereafter stored in desiccators (fused calcium chloride) for drug release experiments. Percentage drug loading (%DL) and %DL efficiency (%LE) was calculated using Equations 4 and 5, respectively- (4)% Drug loading=Drug(In hydrogel)weigh of dry hydrogel×100 (5) % Drug loading efficiency =Drug present in hydrogel discInitial amount of the hydrogel×100

Drug release profile from hydrogel matrices was studied in PBS, pH 6.5 (supplemented with 0.04%w/v of sodium azide, as fungicidal) at 37 ± 0.2°C. The discs were dipped into 5 mL of PBS and shake at 50 rpm in an incubator shaker (Orbitek, India). After predetermined time intervals (0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 10, 13, 16, and 20 days), 1 mL aliquot was withdrawn and replenished with fresh media, optical density of each aliquot (test specimens and blank; matrices without drug) was measured by UV visible spectrophotometer (BioTek, PowerWave ™ XS/XS2), at 286 nm. Standard curve of known concentrations of EGCG was used to calculate the concentration of drug in test aliquot. The drug release profile was further used to calculate release kinetics of EGCG from hydrogels with varying compositions.
The drug release profile of EGCG from various matrices was studied by release kinetics theories, Fick’s law of diffusion and Korsmeyer-Peppas models.26–28

Zero order kinetics equated as (6)Ft=K1t where, Ft (Mt/M∞) is the fraction of drug release at time t, and K1 is zero order release constant. Korsmeyer-Peppas model is equated as- (7)F=K1tn where F (Mt/M∞) is the fraction of drug release at time t, K2 is Korsmeyer release constant, while n is an exponent that characterizes the mechanism of drug release whether it is diffusion controlled or both diffusion and erosion controlled.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: All the animal experimental data were plotted as a mean ± Standard deviation (n ≥ 6). The student t-test was performed to find the significance of the results. p ≤ 0.05 (95% confidence level) was considered significant.

sec.title: Preparation of hydrogel composite
sec.p:
Thermal initiated radical polymerization method was used for the synthesis of P(AAc-Hm)/G hydrogels with poly caprolactone diacrylate (PCL-DAr) as a cross-linker (Scheme 1). APS and TEMED being water-soluble initiators and provide an advantage of initiating the polymerization reaction at low temperature in aqueous media and avoid harsh treatment of the proteineous component. The dissolved oxygen from water was removed by N2 bubbling for 15 min for maximizing polymerization. Additionally, the reaction temperature was kept below 25°C prior to initiator addition to prevent pre-activation of initiators. With consideration of needful biocompatibility, mechanical strength, as well as swelling and degradation profile, monomers and cross-linker were selected. Polyacrylic acid, a hydrophilic polymer, imparts swelling properties to the hydrogels while P(HEMA) contributes for mechanical strength and gelatin, a natural biopolymer, conferred excellent biocompatibility. It also helps in tailoring the characteristic properties of cell proliferation to the matrix for tissue engineering applications. Additionally, in comparison to bisacrylamide and other small molecular weight cross-linkers, PCL-DAr contributes to the elasticity of the hydrogels. Scheme 1.
(a) Schematic representation of multicomponent hydrogel scaffold preparation. (b) Chemical structure of epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG).

sec.title: ATR-FTIR spectroscopy
sec.p:
Figure 2(a), (b), (c), (d), and (e) depicts the ATR-FTIR spectra of gelatin, AAc, HEMA and P(AAc-Hm), and P(AAc-Hm) G semi-IPN. Native gelatin [Figure 2(a)] shows a wide absorption band from 3000 to 3280 cm−1 due to −O–H and N–H stretching vibrations. Characteristic bands at 1626 cm−1, 1530 cm−1, and 1233 cm−1 were assigned, respectively, for amide-I (>C = 0 stretching), amide-II (N–H bending deformation), amide-III (−C–N stretching vibrations) attributed to its random, as well as α-helix conformation.18,29 AAc [Figure 2(b)] shown its characteristic peak at 2983 cm−1, 1697 cm−1 and 1636 cm−1 & 1620 cm−1 assigned for −OH stretching, >C = O stretching vibrations and terminal vinyl functionality, respectively.27 HEMA [Figure 2(c)] shows its characteristic bands at 3428 cm−1, 2852 cm−1, 2957 cm−1, 1636 cm−1, and 1715 cm−1, which are assigned for asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations (terminal hydroxyl group), methylene & methyl stretching, and terminal vinyl, and carbonyl group, respectively. Figure 1.
Photographs of hydrogel matrices; a(i) Poly(HEMA), a(ii) poly(AAc), A(iii) P(AAc5Hm5)G, b, c, and d demonstrate flexibility and elasticity of the P(AAc5Hm5)G hydrogel. Figure 2.
Demonstration of comparative ATR-FTIR spectra of (a) gelatin, (b) acrylic acid (AAc), (c) HEMA, (d) P(AAc5Hm5) crosslink network (IPN), P(AAc5Hm5)G semi-IPN network.

Figure 2d depicts the ATR-FTIR spectra of interpenetrating cross-linked network between PAAc and P(HEMA). Disappearance of terminal vinyl bands around 1635 cm−1 and decreased frequency of −OH stretching from 3428 to 3320 cm−1 as a result of intermolecular hydrogen bonding between −OH and −COOH groups of P(AAc) and P(HEMA) indicate the formation of IPN structure. In case of P(AAc-Hm)G (Figure 2e), an additional peak of >C = O and −NH-CO at 1653 and 1530 cm−1, respectively, appeared because of the presence of gelatin in the interpenetrating composite hydrogels.

sec.title: Thermal gravimetric analysis
sec.p:
Figure 3(a), (b), (c), (d), and (e) shows the TGA thermographs of gelatin, PAAc, P(HEMA), and selected polymers P(AAc5Hm5) and P(AAc5Hm5)G, respectively. Gelatin showed the loss of moisture with degradation of peptide chain scission with char yield of ∼18%. PAAc hydrogels showed three-step degradation pattern, first due to loss of free moisture content (194°C); second, with the formation of anhydride (from 236 to 281°C); and third as a result of main chain scission of polymeric backbone (from 343 to 451°C) with the formation of stable char (23% yield). Figure 3(c), thermograph of P(HEMA) showed one-step degradation attributable to random chain scission with the formation of volatile products (no char yield). The thermal stability of P(HEMA) was found to be higher than PAAc and gelatin. It was interesting to note that thermal degradation of P(AAcHm; Figure 3(d)) did not show the formation of anhydride in the IPN system. In addition to this, thermograph of P(AAcHm) showed higher thermal stability (Tf ∼459°C) in comparison to PAAc and gelatin (Tmax 451°C and 394°C, respectively; Table 1). Both these results reveal the formation of closely packed polymeric network which eventually lead to non-covalent interactions between PAAc and P(HEMA) functionality (−COOH and −OH, respectively) hence, form a stable system. The incorporation of gelatin into the hydrogel network led to less stiffer network, resulting in decreased thermal stability (Tmax 452°C). Author would like to mention that the purpose of TGA studies was to show the effect of the addition of each component on thermal property of the constructs. Figure 3.
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) thermographs of P(AcHmG) hydrogels with varied feed ratio; (a) Gelatin (b) PAAc (c) P(HEMA), (d) P(AAc5Hm5), and (e) P(AAc5Hm5)G.
Table 1.
Comparative thermogravimetric data (Ti, Tf, and Tmax) of the monomers and polymeric hydrogel system.a
Formulation code Ti (°C) Tf (°C) Tmax (°C)
Gelatin 297 394 339
PAAc 356 451 386
P(HEMA) 365 485 428
P(AAc5Hm5) 388 459 437
P(AAc5Hm5)G 367 452 420
a
Data were used as mean of ±SD, n = 3.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p:
Porous internal structure with well-defined internal pores and periphery was observed from SEM micrographs of hydrogels as depicted in Figure 4(a–g). The pore size of hydrogels in their equilibrium swelling state were observed to be 6 ± 2 µm, 7 ± 2 µm, 15 ± 3 µm, 25 ± 4 µm, and 35 ± 4 µm with AAc/HEMA ratio of 3/7, 4/6, 5/5, 6/4, and 7/3, respectively, whereas the pores of 60 ± 10 µm and 5 ± 2 µm diameter was observed in PAAc and P(HEMA) hydrogels. The ratio of AAc/HEMA influenced the swelling properties of matrices, which eventually modulates their morphology and pore size. Swelling of matrices increased with increasing PAAc content (section Swelling properties), which eventually governed the sizing of ice crystals during freezing before lyophilization. Pore size was measured from 10 randomly selected surface areas and the mean ±SD was used to interpret the data. Figure 4.
Scanning electron micrographs of P(AAcHm)G hydrogels with varying feed composition; demonstration of pore size and in-depth morphology; (a) P(AAc3Hm7)G, (b) P(AAc4Hm6)G, (c) P(AAc5Hm5)G, (d) P(AAc6Hm4)G, (e) P(AAc7Hm3)G, (f) PAAc, (g) P(HEMA). Magnification ×5000; Bar line represent 10 µm.
Figure 5.
(A) Equilibrium swelling ratio (ESR) of (a) P(HEMA), (b) P(AAc5Hm5), (c) P(AAc3Hm7)G, (d) P(AAc4Hm6)G, (e) P(AAc5Hm5)G, (f) P(AAc6Hm4)G, (g) P(AAc7Hm3)G, (h) PAAc, in distilled water, phosphate buffer saline (pH 6.5, 7.4) as a function of pH; (B) swelling profile of formulations in distilled water; (a) PAAc, (b) P(AAc7Hm3)G, (c) P(AAc6Hm4)G, (d) P(AAc5Hm5)G, (e) P(AAc4Hm6)G, (f) P(AAc3Hm7)G, P(HEMA) (keeping the cross-linker content constant (0.5 mol% of monomer), 37 ± 0.2°C (SD ± 5%, n = 3).

sec.title: Swelling properties
sec.p: The effect of feed composition on swelling behavior of semi-IPN constructs was investigated in distilled water (DW, pH 5.8) and PBS (pH 6.5 and 7.4). From Figure 5(A) and (B), PAAc and P(HEMA) showed 20 and 1 times equilibrium swelling content (ESR) in DW, respectively. Hydrogels, namely, P(AAc3Hm7)G, P(AAc4Hm6)G, P(AAc5Hm5)G, P(AAc6Hm4)G, and P(AAc7Hm3)G demonstrated the equilibrium swelling upto ∼9, ∼11, ∼14, ∼17, and ∼20 folds, respectively, at pH 6.5 (0.2 M) whereas at pH 7.4, these matrices demonstrated 13, 19, 22, 27, and 29 times swelling. It was observed that ESR increased with increasing pH and AAc/HEMA ratio.

It is well documented that swelling of ionic gels is dependent upon the density of ionizable functional groups of polymers as well as pH and ionic strength of the media.7,11 In contrast, nonionic hydrogels contribute in the swelling by making H-bonds with water molecules. These semi-IPN constructs are made up of ionic (polyacrylic acid, gelatin) as well as non-ionic polymers P(HEMA) thus demonstrated a regulated swelling pattern.

sec.title: Weight loss profile
sec.p:
Figure 6 showed the weight loss profile of semi-IPN constructs. It was observed that semi-IPN constructs with AAc/HEMA ratio of 3/7, 4/6, 5/5, 6/4, and 7/3, namely as P(AAc3Hm7)G, P(AAc4Hm6)G, P(AAc5Hm5)G, P(AAc6Hm4)G, and P(AAc7Hm3)G, lose nearly 7%, 14%, 15% 18%, and 21% of weight within 10 days and nearly 9%, 18%, 23%, 25%, and 27% within 20 days of incubation, respectively. It is hypothesized that under normal incubation conditions, hydrogel lose their weight by two ways, first, due to release of uncross-linked gelatin with increasing swelling of the system, secondly, due to breaking of the cross-linking as a result of cleavage of ester bonds of PCL-DAr with the formation of macromers of long chain P(AAc-Hm). Polyacrylic acid and P(HEMA) both are essentially nondegradable system, but incorporation of gelatin enhance the swelling of the matrices in buffer media which eventually leads to the leaching of gelatin out of the matrices. Due to incorporation of gelatin, comparatively a loose network was formed which led the matrices to leach the gelatin in a time-dependent manner, which eventually enhanced the EGCG release profile too. Figure 6.
It should be weight loss profile of P(AAcHm)G hydrogels with varying AAc/HEMA ratio in PBS (pH-7.4, 0.2M, at 37 ± 0.2°C.) (A) P(HEMA), (B) PAAc, (C) P(AAc3Hm7)G, (D) P(AAc4Hm6)G, (E) P(AAc5Hm5)G, (F) P(AAc6Hm4)G, (G) P(AAc7Hm3)G, % weight loss as a function of time (days), (SD ± 5%, n = 3).

sec.title: Compressive modulus
sec.p:
Figure7A demonstrated the force versus displacement plot of hydrogels with varying AAc/HEMA ratio, which was used to obtain the value of stress and strain. From these values, compression modulus was calculated. The compression modulus of PAAc and P(HEMA) was found to be 11.6 KPa and 203 KPa (at 30% strain value) whereas their displacement value at 20N force was observed to be 4.7 to 3.2 mm, respectively (Table 2). In case of hydrogels, gradual increment in compression modulus (from 53.2 ± 1.1 to 92 ± 3.4) was observed with increased HEMA/AAc ratio (from 3/7 to 7/3) of the matrices. This could be the result of comparatively reduced swelling capacity of hydrogels with higher P(HEMA) content (swelling properties of the matrices; Figure 5). It also offered lesser amount of water to be available in the matrix for displacement during compression resulting in decreased displacement values with increasing HEMA content (p < 0.05). Moreover, these semi-IPN constructs did not break even at maximum compression and were elastic enough to revert back to their original state after the test. On the other hand, P(HEMA) hydrogel got fractured before maximum compression. Figure 7.
(A) Evaluation of compression properties of hydrogel matrices; Comparative plots between force vs displacement of hydrogels as a function of AAc/HEMA ratio; (a) P(HEMA), (b) P(AAc3Hm7)G, (c) P(AAc4Hm6)G, (d) P(AAc5Hm5)G, (e) P(AAc6Hm4)G, (f) P(AAc7Hm3)G, (g) PAAc; (B) Universal compression testing machine; Hydrogel sample placed in between two metal platforms for assessment of compression properties, (SD ± 5%, n = 5, p < 0.05).
Table 2.

P(AAc7Hm3)G 0 10 53.2 ± 1.1* 4.4 ± 0.9* 0.509 0.980
a
Compression properties were measured as a function of PAAc/P(HEMA) ratio; (n = 5, *p < 0.05; in comparison to PAAc); and drug release profile was studied in PBS (pH 6.5); Expression of diffusional exponent and regression values were mentioned.

sec.title: Cytocompatibility analysis and cell proliferation studies
sec.p:
MTT assay is a well-recognized and quick method to evaluate cytocompatibility of the biomaterials as a preliminary biocompatibility test before proceeding to in vivo applications. The assay is based on reduction of MTT into insoluble violet color formazan crystals by mitochondrial enzymes of viable cells. Indirect MTT assay method (using extracts of composite matrices) ensures the possible availability of any toxic chemicals (unreacted monomers) in the formulations as well as ensures the flawless polymerization reaction during their preparation. Calcein AM penetrates the cell membrane of living cells. Once inside, the cellular esterase present in living cells hydrolyze it into calcien, which is cell membrane-impermeable and gives its emission maximum at 515 nm. The cell viability was tested after 24 h of incubation of extract. From Figure 8, it was found that in all the formulations, more than 92.3 ± 2% viability was observed in comparison to positive control (gelatin). Additionally, percentage viability did not change with varying extract volume. Cell viability data were calculated from Equation 3 and as a mean of ±SD, n = 6. Figure 8.
Cytotoxicity studies (fibroblast L929) of P(AAcHm)G hydrogels with varying formulation compositions at three concentrations of extracts (25, 50, and 100 µL). (a) PAAc, (b) P(HEMA) (C) P(AAc3Hm7)G, (D) P(AAc4Hm6)G, (E) P(AAc5Hm5)G, (F) P(AAc6Hm4)G, (G) P(AAc7Hm3)G, Triton-X-100 and gelatin were used as negative and positive control, respectively. Data used as a mean ± SD (n = 6).

To know the effect of matrix surface on cell proliferation, fibroblast L929 cells were seeded and their morphology and quantity were evaluated on days 1, 3, and 5. Cells stained with Calcien AM demonstrated that with decreasing AAc/HEMA ratio from 1:0 to 1:1 (i.e. P(AAc1Hm0)/G to P(AAc1Hm1)/G), a significant improvement was observed in the cell quantity on the surface of matrices (Figure 9). The attached cells found their natural morphology and confluency on day 5. Increasing HEMA content decreased the anionic properties of the scaffolds, as a result, the cell attachment and proliferation were found to enhance. Figure 9.
Fluorescent micrographs of Calcien AM stained fibroblast L929 cells on the surface of (A) P(AAc1Hm0)/G, (B) P(AAc1Hm0.5)/G, and (C) P(AAc1Hm1)/G, (×20 magnification) after days 1, 3, and 5.

Due to the presence of −COO− groups, PAc surface is anionic in nature. It is well-known that neutral and anionic surfaces do not allow negatively charged cell membrane to attach on the surface. Therefore in this study, PAc content of the matrices was replaced with gelatin (upto its maximum loading concentration) while P(HEMA) content increased from 0 to 100 and of PAc ration (w/w). Thereby, with decreasing PAc content to 30% by P(HEMA) and 40% by gelatin, we were able to make an interpenetrating network that allowed the cells to attach and proliferate. In addition, crucial hydrogel properties such as swelling, biocompatibility and mechanical properties were retained.

sec.title: Drug loading and release profile
sec.p: EGCG was loaded by diffusion method. The dry sample discs were incubated into the required quantity of aqueous solution of EGCG for 24 h at room temperature. The amount of distilled water used for drug dissolution was estimated to ensure that whole of the solution will get absorbed without spilling. The loosely adhered drug on the discs surface was removed by dipping of discs in distilled water for 10 s following drying at room temperature for further drug release experiments. Percentage drug loading and percentage loading efficiency of hydrogels was found to be 1.85 ± 0.55% and 96 ± 1.5%, respectively. %DL increased with increasing AAc/HEMA ratio in the hydrogels, since swelling in distilled water was increasing in the same ratio. On the other hand, %LE was also regulated by swelling capacity of matrices.

Figure 10 depicts the percentage cumulative release profile of EGCG from all formulation with respect to time. It was noticed that almost ∼53% and ∼74% of drug has been released from PAAc hydrogels within 48 h and 96 h, in contrast to 26% and 38% from P(HEMA) hydrogels. On the other hand, only 9% of total drug remains into the PAAc hydrogel network in contrast to 38% from P(HEMA) hydrogels after 20 days. In case of hydrogels, nearly 27%, 33%, 40%, and 38% of drug released within 48 h while ∼41%, ∼50%, ∼57%, and ∼58% of drug released within 96 h from P(AAc4Hm6)G, P(AAc5Hm5)G, P(AAc6Hm4)G, and P(AAc7Hm3)G hydrogels. The drug release data from these formulations indicate that with increasing PAAc content of the matrices, cumulative release of EGCG increased. These results can be explained on the basis of the influence of swelling and weight loss profile of the matrices (under the sub-section ‘swelling properties’ and ‘weight loss profile’, Fgures 5 and 6). In buffer media (pH 6.5, 0.2 M), ionic repulsion of carboxyl ions (−COO−) resulted into expansion of polyacrylic acid chains thereby, gelatin was released from the matrices as per AAc/HEMA ratio. This led to faster and complete release of drug from the network having higher PAAc content while maximum drug retained inside P(HEMA) hydrogels (i.e. least swelling). Due to interpenetrating network formation of three polymeric components, PAAc, P(HEMA), and gelatin, sustained release profile of EGCG was observed in comparison to pure hydrogels [i.e. PAAc and P(HEMA)]. Tailoring of formulation compositions according to needful sustained release of EGCG for in-vivo wound healing applications is a crucial and novel feature of these formulations. Drug-polymer interactions also play a significant role in its release from the matrix. Physical interaction of hydroxyl (−OH) groups of EGCG with free functional groups of gelatin (−NH2, −COOH,) and PAAc (−COOH) make the drug to remain inside the network and which act like a depot for EGCG-sustained release (as depicted in ATR-FTIR spectra of EGCG laden semi-IPN matrix; Supplementary data). Downward shifting and reduced intensity of −C = O of PAAc at 1716 cm−1 from 1723 cm−1 as well as shifting of bands from 1653, 1543, and 1453 cm−1 to 1636, 1530, and 1446 cm−1, respectively, indicated the formation of H-bonds between EGCG and P(AAcHm)/G semi-IPN constructs. It was found that approximately (90%) and (58%) of the drug was released from PAAC hydrogel and P(AAcHm)G composite hydrogel in the presence of H-bonds among (−COOH,−OH) of polymers chains and EGCG. It indicates that swelling was the main contributing factor for EGCG release behavior from PAc system while swelling as well as gelatin release both regulate the drug release behavior of P(AcHm)G matrices. Figure 10.
Cumulative release profile of epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG) formulation having varying compositions in PBS (pH 6.5, 37 ± 0.2°C) at 75 rpm. (a) PAAc, (b) P(AAc7Hm3)G, (c) P(AAc5Hm5)G (d) P(AAc6Hm4)G, (e) P(AAc4Hm6)G, (f) P(AAc3Hm7)G, and (g) P(HEMA). Data were used as a mean ± SD, n = 3, (SD ± 5%, n = 3).

sec.title: Drug release kinetics
sec.p: The linearity was calculated by plotting the logarithm of the % drug release versus logarithm of time. The exponent (n) reveals the dynamics of EGCG release from hydrogels, which was calculated from Equation 7. According to Korsmeyer-Peppas equation,26 fickian diffusion (Case-I transport) occurs when n ≤ 0.5, while non-Fickian release (anomalous transport) is assumed when 0.5 < n < 1.0. From the slope of the linear plot of In (f) versus In (t), the diffusion exponent value (n) was obtained. The diffusion exponent value (n) for formulation PAAc, P(HEMA), P(AAc3Hm7)G, P(AAc4Hm6)G, P(AAc5Hm5)G, P(AAc6Hm4)G, and P(AAc7Hm3)G was found to be 0.354, 0.398, 0.529, 0.611, 0.536, 0.535, and 0.504, respectively (Table 2). It was observed that single component hydrogels followed the fickian rule (n value < 0.5), whereas, hydrogels followed both diffusion and erosion mechanism (n value >0.5).

Hydrogels were made-up of various monomer/polymer components (Table 2) where AAc and HEMA were crosslinked with PCL-DAr whereas, gelatin chains remain free and were intercalating into the 3-dimentional P(AAC-HEMA) network. From the value of diffusion exponent (n), the plot of In (f) versus In (t), it was found that release of EGCG from interpenetrating network was governed by PAAc/P(HEMA) ratio. With increasing PAAc and decreasing P(HEMA) concentration, the value of diffusion coefficient (n) varied from 0.529 to 0.504, while in case of hydrogels [PAAc & P(HEMA)], the n values were found to be less than 0.5, hence it was suggested that solvent (PBS) penetration was a rate-limiting step in dense polymeric network (Hydrogels) thereby, EGCG from these networks was released primarily by diffusion mechanism.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Conclusively, biocompatible 3-dimentional multicomponent hydrogels were successfully prepared by redox-initiated thermal polymerization, where gelatin chains intercalated in between P(AAc/HEMA) cross-linked network. The composite matrix played significant role in cell proliferation, elasticity, and drug release. Gelatin helped in the cell attachment and proliferation, whereas the composite hydrogel matrices of P(HEMA) and PAAc not only provides hydrated environment for the optimum cell growth but also the strength and elasticity that furthermore regulate drug release profile. Moreover, their tunable physical properties, sustained release of EGCG, cytocompatibility, and cell proliferation performance gave an outlook to utilize these formulations for pharmaceutical and soft tissue engineering.

ack.p: Maneesh Jaiswal is thankful to the Indian Council of Medical Research, India, for Senior research fellowship and to Dr. Sujata Mohanty and Mr. Krishan Kr jain, Stem Cell Facility, All India Institute of Medical Sciences, Delhi, India, for cell culture studies.
